PREFACE
The following oral history testimony is the result of a videotaped interview with Ernest
Culman, conducted on February 24, 2006 on behalf of the United States Holocaust Memorial
Museum. The interview is part of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum's collection of
oral testimonies. Rights to the interview are held by the United States Holocaust Memorial
Museum.

ERNEST CULMAN
February 24, 2006

segments.question: Good morning.
segments.answer: Good morning.

segments.question: It’s nice to see you, Ernest.
segments.answer: Thank you, same here.

segments.question: What was your name at birth?
segments.answer: Ernst.

segments.question: Ernst.
segments.answer: E-r-n-s-t, Ernst, pronounce in German it’s Ernst.

segments.question: And now it’s Ernest, is that right.
segments.answer: Ernest.

segments.question: And your last name?
segments.answer: Culman, and it used to be spo -- spelled with two n’s, but I dropped one n.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: To be less Germanic.

segments.question: So it used to be C-u-l-m-a-n-n?
segments.answer: That’s correct.

segments.question: And now it’s with one n.
segments.answer: One n.

segments.question: Okay. And when were you born?
segments.answer: December second, 1929.

segments.question: And where? This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: In a town called Liegnitz, which was Germany at the time. It became part of Poland after World War II. It’s now referred to as Legnica in Poland.

segments.question: So it was the eastern part of Germany’?
segments.answer: Eastern part of Germany in the area called Silesia.

segments.question: Right. Let’s talk a little bit about your home life. What wa -- what was your dad’s name?
segments.answer: My Dad’s name was August. He was a physician, a general practitioner. And he actually started his practice in 1910. So he was a physician in Liegnitz for 30 years.

segments.question: Wow.
segments.answer: And he married later in life, he was 40 years old by the time he got married. He was 45 by the time I was born. And --

segments.question: So he was -- he was married when, 1924?
Five. And then you’re born in 1929.
Right. And was your mother older also, or she was considerably younger than your father?
segments.answer: Well, my mother was 10 years younger than my father --

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: -- but was still -- you know, and she was 35 when I was born.

segments.question: Right, right. And your mother’s name?
segments.answer: My mother’s name was Betty, her maiden name was Lewy, L-e-w-y.

segments.question: Right. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: And in German it was pronounced Levy. But it’s Lewy in --

segments.question: Over here.
segments.answer: [indecipherable] would like it s -- being spelled.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: Most time Levy is with a -- a v, this was with a w.

segments.question: So, let’s talk about what your earliest memories of home life in -- in Germany, what -- do you remember what it was like? Do you remember your apartment, or your hou -- did you live in a house or apartment?
segments.answer: No, we had a big apartment, actually it were two apartments that were opened up together. Half of them was my father’s offices and practice, and the other half is where we lived. I can still see it in my eyes, it was a long, drawn out apartment, there was a big living room, and dining room that were connected together. Then there was a long hall that was long enough for me to ride my tricycle on. At the other end were the bedrooms, and big bathroom, and all that. And then there were about three rooms that were my father’s offices. One thing I remember in that big hallway, we had an icebox, I mean, not a refrigerator, but an icebox. It was pink.

segments.question: Pink?
segments.answer: Pink icebox. And you know, in summer the iceman came by in his horse and buggy and brought up those big pieces of ice to put in there.

segments.question: When you say icebox, it means that there’s ice that’s make -- making the area cold so you can have food in there, or 1s it just for ice?
segments.answer: No, ice for -- like a refrigerator, but not electric.

segments.question: Right, right. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: It was a -- I mean, we had electricity, and we had running water, and regular toilets and all that, but many of the modern electrical stuff we didn’t have as yet.

segments.question: Right. And how often did this guy come with the ice, do you remember’?
segments.answer: No, I couldn’t tell you that honestly. My guess would be about once a week.

segments.question: Uh-huh. But they were these huge, big pieces of ice, right?
segments.answer: Those huge, big pieces of ice, and --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- the melting of the ice truck down, ran behind it as little kids to get some of that cold water on your face --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- on a hot, sunny day.

segments.question: Did you have your own bedroom?
segments.answer: No, my -- I shared it with my brother. And we got along fine.

segments.question: You did?
segments.answer: Most of the -- most of the time.

segments.question: Five years is a big.
segments.answer: No, it’s actually four years.

segments.question: Four year -- four years, rather. It’s a pretty big difference.
segments.answer: Yes, it is a big difference, and we did have our fights, of course he was bigger and stronger than I, sometimes very aggravating. He would just hold out his hand and I couldn’t get anywhere near him. But we did fine. I wasn’t very aware of us being different from other kids in the neighborhood and the building. The building was owned by a man who has the carpentry shop in the back. There was a little alley where we played in, and then there was this big factory, where This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection you heard the machinery going almost day and night. Well, not night of course, but I do remember that very well.

segments.question: Right. So was this a -- a mixed neighborhood, or were you the only Jews in the neighborhood that you remember?
segments.answer: Um.

segments.question: When you said that you didn’t feel different --
segments.answer: We were little bit on the outskirts, not a suburb like you see here, but in a working class area. Not in the downtown area of our little town. And most of the Jewish family lived more in the downtown area. So there were not too many Jewish people living there, but we -- the town wasn’t that big to begin with --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- so we had good contact with them. The streetcar ran right in front of our house, and streetcar was a single track. And in the front of our house there was a bike path. So when one came from one side, the other one had to wait --

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: -- for it to come from the other side. And -- but we walked most places. We walked to school, and walked to the synagogue and all that.

segments.question: Were you religious, was the family religious [indecipherable]
segments.answer: No, not religious at all. My mother’s family was religious, but we were not at all, my father was not at all. However, we did belong to the synagogue with -- my parents had the respective seats there. On high holidays that men sat downstairs, the women upstairs.

segments.question: So it was -- was it Orthodox?
segments.answer: It was Conservative -- This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: -- it wasn’t Orthodox.

segments.question: It’s a very -- rather Conservative.
segments.answer: A little.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: Leaning on the Conservative --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- side, but --

segments.question: So you didn’t go on a regular basis every week, you went on holidays?
segments.answer: We did go frequently on Friday night.

segments.question: You did?
segments.answer: In fact, we also attended what we would call Sunday school here, but actually Hebrew school.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: And three boys and three girls always got called up for Kiddush onto the beamer, and the joke was that my brother didn’t care for the wine but he had to drink it, but I enjoyed it every time that I got up there.

segments.question: Enjoy --
segments.answer: My mother was more religious than my father, but we didn’t keep kosher or anything like that.

segments.question: You didn’t?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: Did -- did your mother light candles on Friday night?
segments.answer: Most of the time. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection

segments.question: Most of the time, uh-huh.
segments.answer: And quite often we had friends over for Friday night dinner.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: But, you know, candle lighting was about as far as we went. My mother did fast on yi -- Yom Kippur.

segments.question: Did you?
segments.answer: Not until I was Bar Mitzvah and then I fasted and most of the time still do.

segments.question: Really? That’s interesting.
segments.answer: But that’s about the only thing I’m sort of keeping.

segments.question: It is. Right. So what was home life like? Did you all eat lunch together since your father was working there? Did he take off lunchtime and have lunch with you?
segments.answer: Not necessarily, he --

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: -- but we had lunch -- we had servants, we had the -- my father had a nurse for his office. We had a live in maid.

segments.question: Oh, you did?
segments.answer: And she took care of the house, but she didn’t take care of the kids, my mother took care of my brother and I.

segments.question: That’s interesting.
segments.answer: We took many walks. The little town was quite picturesque. Had nice parks that we went through. And my father, having lived there for such a long time, was well known in the city. Old type physician, he got called out at night quite frequently.

segments.question: So he was well known as a physician as well. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: As a physician as well --

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: -- especially in the neighborhood that we were in.

segments.question: Uh-huh. Was he a general practitioner?
segments.answer: Yes, he was.

segments.question: So he did all sorts of things, but he didn’t do surgery, I gather?
segments.answer: He did not do surgery. There were other people who were there who did surgery.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And took trips to the little farms outside, and I often went with him. I remember going with him on a -- to a farm and get s -- got scared when all these big dogs and what have you came snooping around the car while he was in there with his patient. And as I got a little older, learned to ride a bike, many of the calls he made were by bicycle, and I went with him on a bicycle. It was on one of those trips where I was riding in front of him, and we talked back and forth, all of a sudden I don’t -- didn’t get an answer. I look around and I see him off the bike, he had had a heart attack.

segments.question: Oh my.
segments.answer: A very severe heart attack. It was a friend of ours, not living too far from where we were, we went to her house and called a taxi to take us home. And this was his first, and very severe heart attack.

segments.question: Huh. And do you remember what year that was? Was that befor -- must have been before Kristallnacht.
segments.answer: Yes, this was before Kristallnacht. It was maybe one or two years before that.

segments.question: So you were quite young? This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: I was six years old or so.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: And --

segments.question: So your brother was not traveling with your dad on bicycle, just --
segments.answer: No, my brother went through the elementary school in our town, and then when it came for him to go to high school he was transferred to Breslau.

segments.question: Oh.
segments.answer: Now called Wroclaw, where my mother’s family lived. And he lived with one of my uncle and aunt’s and attended school there. So he wasn’t home at the time.

segments.question: I see, I see. So did your dad go to the hospital, or did he stay home?
segments.answer: He stayed home.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: He got taken care of at home.

segments.question: Was he then able to go back to his medical practice after the heart attack, or did that --
segments.answer: Yes, but it took quite a few months.

segments.question: It did?
segments.answer: Quite a few months, and he was all right then. It was probably -- probably in early 1938, because after he got well, we decided to move to a smaller apartment. And it was in that smaller apartment where we then experienced the Kristallnacht.

segments.question: I see. So Hitler and the Nazis take over in 1933, so you’re -- there -- something is going on. Do you notice a change --
segments.answer: Oh yes.

segments.question: -- as you’re growing up? This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: I -- I didn't notice a change, really, because all I knew was --

segments.question: Was that.
segments.answer: -- Hitler.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: I mean, all I knew was the Nazi government.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: You know, at three years you have no knowledge of what is going on.

segments.question: Right, right.
segments.answer: The street we lived on, there were often parades moving along the street, and as a little child you love -- you love a parade --

segments.question: Sure.
segments.answer: -- you like to be out there and cheering them on with the other kids. And somehow I knew I’m not supposed to cheer these people on. But it was very difficult for me to fully understand what there was.

segments.question: Right. Did your parents talk to you about this --
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: -- at all, and say, you know, don’t go out there, be careful, or --
segments.answer: Th -- be careful, don’t go out there, and tha -- but they left it fairly open. [indecipherable] other words, they didn’t make too much of a deal out of it. But I always knew certain things we can’t do. Just certain rules we as Jews couldn’t do. Because my parents had a live in maid, they celebrated Christmas in a way, in fact we had a Christmas tree. The maid wanted it of course, and so we celebrated Christmas. And one year my parents called my brother and I together and This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection said, we’re not going to celebrate Christmas any more, we’re going to celebrate Chanukah from now on. And our main question was, will we still get gifts.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And long as that was the case, we didn’t care.

segments.question: Didn’t care, right. Now, did your maid have to leave at -- I -- I’m assuming that she was not Jewish, the maid?
segments.answer: She was not Jewish.

segments.question: Did she have to leave your household at a certain point?
segments.answer: Yes. A certain point, the law came about that she had to be, I think fo -- 35 or 45 --

segments.question: I think it’s 45 [indecipherable]
segments.answer: 45 old, and this was a very young person, and she had to leave the house at midnight, December 31“, whatever year it was. And she stayed til the very last minute, and then left. And my parents actually found somebody else, 40 f -- was just 45, to take over. This person had been a cook in a sanitarium, she knew how to cook very well, and she taught my mother how to cook.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: The second -- they were both called Marthe, the second Marthe. And when we moved into the smaller apartment and she didn’t come wi -- come with us.

segments.question: She didn’t come. So when you had the maid, the maid was cleaning and cooking, and --
segments.answer: Cleaning and cooking.

segments.question: -- your mother was taking care of the two of you.
segments.answer: Right. Of course, the maid was there as a babysitter --

segments.question: Right, right.
segments.answer: -- when my parents wanted to go out. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection

segments.question: So you spent a lot of time with both of your parents, I gather.
segments.answer: Lot of time with my mother, because my father was --

segments.question: Was working, right.
segments.answer: Working quite hard. But we frequently took vacations. In fact, we were fairly close to the Czech border.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: And over a weekend we would go into Czechoslovakia, just to get out of there.

segments.question: Right. And how would you travel, by train?
segments.answer: By car.

segments.question: By car? You had a car?
segments.answer: My father had a car. The car was not parked at the house because you couldn’t, you know, it was in a garage maybe a mile away.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And you had to get it from there. But we traveled by car all over the place, quite often. Then when we went into Breslau to live with my mother’s family, we often went by train.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: And my grandmother, when she came to visit us, came by train. And where my brother was going to school in Breslau, on the weekend he came home and frequently I used to pick him up at the train station and we would walk home, just the two of us.

segments.question: Right, right. Did you miss him when he was away? When -- or was it actually nice for you to be able to be alone in the house?
segments.answer: [honestly can’t answer that. I don’t -- I don’t know.

segments.question: Okay, right. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: I don’t know. I -- I guess it was a little bit of both.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: He was always my big brother, he was always there to help me out, all my life. And I don’t know whether I felt it’s nice to be alone.

segments.question: Right, right.
segments.answer: I-I don’t think I did. Because I went to school by this time also.

segments.question: You started school when, when you were six or five?
segments.answer: Six.

segments.question: When you were six.
segments.answer: But when I was five years old I went to a nursery school, a kindergarten, I mean --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- here we -- it’s part of the school system, there it was separate. The same lady was in charge of that kindergarten that was in charge when my brother went there. And by this time it was 1935 or SO.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: And, you know -- you know, it’s 1935, and I remember very clearly the door ringing at our house, and I opened the door. There is Miss Schroeder with a big bouquet of flowers, and tears in her eyes, coming to see my mother. Well, it turned out that one of the other kids, five year old kid, his parents objected to t-to being -- to having a Jew in his kindergarten class. So this was my first experience of anti-Semitism. So obviously I had to leave, and Miss Schroeder couldn’t do anything, and this guy was also a physician, the father of this other kid. So I had to leave. But this was shortly before I had to enter regular school. And when my mother took me to school my first day of school, it turned out that that same kid would be in the same class as me. So she went This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection to the principal, explained the situation, and he put me into a parallel class. Turned out that I was the only Jewish kid in the whole school, but at least I wasn’t in with this one.

segments.question: And no one else complained, it was this -- it was this --
segments.answer: I-In the kindergarten it was this particular person. And I made friends in school, like any kid. Got real friendly with two other boys, they were separate, boys and girls were separate in that school. And one kid had a birthday party, he invited me, the other one was fine, and of course my time to have a birthday party, I invited both of them, they both said they’d come. The next day one of them said, “I’m sorry, but my parents won’t let me come.”

segments.question: Oh.
segments.answer: And I remembered his name, his name was Webber, his last name was Webber. Many years later, I was in the amer -- I was this G.I. in the American army, stationed back in Europe, and I tried to make contact with my former teacher. And somebody wrote me, my name is Webber, you must remember, you went to school with my brother, and basically they wanted some help. So I wrote him back, yes I remember him very well. You didn’t want to have any contact with a Jew, now you do? But the nice thing at that point was that I made contact with my grade school teacher. He was a wonderful person. When Crystal Night came about, I went to school. The synagogue was far enough away from us that I didn’t see what was going on, we were not in the downtown area where all this Jewish retail stores got ruined. And I found out in school what had occurred. And when I came home, my mother received me at the door in tears. My father had been called out to somebody who had been beaten by the Gestapo. And while he was in that person’s house, they came to our house to -- for my father. He was then picked up at his patient’s home and taken to prison. And after that, every day, this teacher, his name was Thiel, came and sat on -- next to me on my chair, is your dad home yet? Every day. After five days my da -- dad This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection did come home. The chief of police in our little town took it upon himself not to send anybody to the concentration camp that had been an officer in the German army. And as a physician, my father was a lieutenant during World War I, so after five days he came home. Right after he came home the word came out that Jews are not allowed to go to public school any more. So they kept me home, my parents kept me home. Mr. Thiel, when he saw me on the street afterwards, would stop his -- jump off his bike, he used to travel around bike, and see how I was doing. And when my birthday came around, he came to our house to bring all the papers, and all the books that I had. And he told my mother he was so glad that I didn’t show up that day because the principal sent somebody in, you’ve got the only Jew in the whole school, send him home. And he hadn’t -- didn’t have to do that in front of the other kids. So I got in contact with him in 1951 - ’?52. We have corresponded for awhile, he was in a little town too far off the beaten track --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- for me to visit him.

segments.question: But he must -- he was quite different, right, he just --
segments.answer: He -- he -- he wasn’t --

segments.question: -- he must have been taking a chance to do what he was doing.
segments.answer: He took a big chance --

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: -- with what he was doing.

segments.question: How did this affect you [indecipherable] as a little boy? Do you re -- do you remember?
segments.answer: I don’t know how to answer that, how it affected me, it’s -- in a way I took it in stride. It became normal. The discrimination against you became a normal thing. Sounds ridiculous if I say it now, but that’s the feeling I have. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And --

segments.question: No, but it makes sense. It becomes part of the pattern of your life.
segments.answer: It becomes the pattern of life -- excuse me -- as I said, my brother was in Breslau, and he was in Breslau at Crystal Night.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: He came home somehow or another, just be with us. But shortly after that was his birthday, his 13" birthday, his Bar Mitzvah. There was no Torah left in Liegnitz because the synagogue got burned. So he brought his Torah home from Breslau. Some of the little shuls were in areas that they couldn’t burn, and there was a few Torahs left. He carried one on the train from Breslau back to Liegnitz. And we had the Bar Mitzvah in our house. And where we lived, that smaller apartment, the second and third floor was a Jewish old age home, and we shared a larger apartment with another family. And that’s where we had his Bar Mitzvah. Many people had come home from concentration camp. This is 1938. We have -- the family showed that they have intentions of leaving, they got out of the concentration camp.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: I remember these people coming home with shaven heads.

segments.question: You do?
segments.answer: [indecipherable |

segments.question: Were you told where they had come from?
segments.answer: Oh yes.

segments.question: You had. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: Yeah. I mean, concentration camp was an everyday word. An uncle of mine, the one that my brother lived with, in the family, he was taken into concentration camp earlier than Kristallnacht. There was some activity, I forgot what they called it, where if you had any -- done anything illegal years before, you end up -- you got taken into prison again. My uncle did some cheating, I guess, on the income tax, I don’t know, at one point it got punitive action, he paid his penalty, but that wasn’t enough. They used that excuse to take him. And he couldn’t take it, he went up against the electric fence, got killed right then and there. My mother had a picture of him in Shanghai, and had it on one of the tables, a man came in one time, he said, I know this man. I saw him getting shot against the ca -- against the fence.

segments.question: Wow.
segments.answer: And --

segments.question: This is your mother -- one of your mother’s brothers?
segments.answer: My mother’s sister’s husband.

segments.question: Sister’s husband, I see.
segments.answer: And, so all these things were told to me, I heard about them.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: Was all part of our life.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: They had sent their son to England to go to school, Cambridge. That’s why they had the room free for my brother to live in.

And some of the other kids had s -- said, I didn’t know you were Jewish. They didn’t realize I was. And that was tough because I went outside, I was the only one in the whole school, for an hour. segments.answer: Oh he -- no, he --

segments.answer: He was still allowed to practice, and at one point he was not allowed to practice any more except for Jews.

segments.question: Mm-hm.

segments.question: And do you remember a significant difference in -- in -- in him, once that happened?
segments.answer: Yes. He became much more serious to me, much more ver -- worried about everything. Seriously starting to talk about emigrating, getting out of Germany. Started to check into going to Palestine. And this was before Crystal Night. Then, after Crystal Night we made contact with far enough relatives in the United States. Our papers at the office, the Palestine office got burned, so everything there got -- had to be started from scratch again.

segments.question: This was burned during Kristallnacht?
segments.answer: Crystal Night.

segments.question: Uh-huh, right.
segments.answer: And, you know, in my mind as a child, I was looking forward to this big trip we’re going to take someplace, somewhere. And some people started talking about going to Shanghai. Shanghai, being an international city, it -- you didn’t need any papers, any visas, or anything like that. All you needed was to get on a ship and get there. But it had a bad reputation, and people This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection didn’t want to go there, including my parents. So one time after Crystal Night, we had friends over the house for a dinner -- I don’t know if it was a Friday night dinner or not, but one person said, you know what? I’m not sticking around her any more. I’m going to Shanghai. Second person said I’Il join you, my father said, I'll join you. If that wouldn’t have happened, we probably would have been stuck in Germany. By this time we had an affidavit from the United States and in my parent’s mind we’ll go to Shanghai for a year or two until our number gets called up and then we go to the States.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: And that’s how we eventually ended up in Shanghai.

segments.question: Did they tell you anything about Shanghai when they si -- made this decision? Or had you heard that this was --
segments.answer: I just heard --

segments.question: -- that this was a strange place.
segments.answer: It’s a strange place, you know, I looked it up on an atlas where it is. In the meantime, my -- a couple of my uncles her -- moo -- moved to Panama, and I followed on the atlas where they went, you know, we all -- all the trips of course were by ship, it wasn’t by plane. So he stopped at many different places. And I was looking forward to this adventure. So we decided to go on a Dutch liner instead of a German or Italian like most people did. The advantage on a Dutch liner is that the so-called board money, you could take right out. The Germans allowed you x number of dollars, or marks, of course, to take on board the ship, to spend on the ship, but not to take off the ship. So when you went on a German liner, they strictly adhere to that. On the Dutch liner that we went to, the purser said to my father, well didn’t you lose x number of dollars gambling This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: Whatever amount that was.

segments.question: Do you remember packing for Shanghai?
segments.answer: Oh yes, very well.

segments.question: Yeah?
segments.answer: To get all your heavy stuff on, you got from the freight company something they called a lift, which was like a big box, size of a room, and everything gets put in there. And when you were packing that, somebody from the Gestapo was there watching what you were packing. Well, when they came to do this packing, my mother sent me outside to play. And I had some play money, which was back from the German inflation in the 20’s, had absolutely no value. And she was getting ready to pack that, and the guy from the Gestapo was -- put up a fuss, you can’t take that. And she was arguing, that’s my kid’s play money, it has no value. I don’t know for sure any more whether we left -- let him keep it or not, but I told my mother, “Let him have it, I don’t care.” You know, it’s just play money.

segments.question: So did you come in and out when --
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: -- when these guys were there?
segments.answer: Yes, yes, I walked in and --

segments.question: Were they nasty? What were they like?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: No? This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: They were actually a little nasty at the beginning and then my mother gave them a drink, and they calmed down a bit. And some of the little knickknacks that we had, she gave one person this and one person that. It wasn’t really bribery in any sense, but it softens them up in a way.

segments.question: Right, right.
segments.answer: And my parents also had the idea that maybe we can get off the ship somewhere before we get to Shanghai. I mean, India was still part of Britain, the Philippines was part of the United States, Singapore was part of Britain. We thought we could maybe get off there.

segments.question: Right, right.
segments.answer: So they decided that this lift with all our belongings should be kept by the freight company until they got the word from us.

segments.answer: Instead -- instead of being shipped at the same time as we were.

segments.question: Right, right.

Ended up in Shanghai and then contacted the freight company, she -- send it to us, this is our address. But in the meantime it’s July of 1939. By the time this lift gets onto a freighter 1t’s September, and the war breaks out. And all German ships get the signal, go into a neutral port. The Dutch is -- East Indies, which are now Indonesia, were still neutral, so the ship ran into a neutral port in Dutch East Indies, and we had to pay a fair amount of money to get it from there to Shanghai.

segments.answer: Send --

segments.answer: -- he had managed to go to Palestine and join the British Brigade at Palestine. And eventually she joined him in Palestine.

segments.question: [indecipherable] each place that she went.

segments.question: Right, right.

segments.answer: It was -- took about six weeks.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Well, I have a tendency to get seasick very easily.

segments.question: But you didn’t know that.
segments.answer: I didn’t know that beforehand. But the Dutch liner was a luxury liner and they had special -- in the dining room the children were not allowed to eat with the parents and I hated that idea. So I was in a separate room with the little kids, you know, the two and three years old --

segments.answer: -- and o -- me at nine years old, I felt I was big enough to do that, you know, to be with my parents.

segments.answer: I didn’t like that at all.

segments.answer: And you would still see land when I got seasick the first time. I don’t know whether that has to do with seasickness or just anxiety about being left alone. But eventually it got alright, had ping pong tables, I learned to count to 21 in -- in Dutch.

segments.answer: Yes, we --

segments.question: You had?
segments.answer: We had, so --

segments.answer: Mr. and Mrs. Ritter, and Mr. and Mrs. Braun, Braun, and a Mr. Salinger. We were nine people altogether. Mr. and Mrs. Braun were the people that we shared this apartment with in Germany -- in Liegnitz.

segments.answer: They had three children, they had left Germany before that. One went to Argentina, one went to Holland, and one went to England.

segments.answer: They were older kids. Little older, not that much older.

segments.answer: Teena -- late teenagers --

segments.question: Right, right.
segments.answer: -- I believe, or maybe early 20’s, or -- I have no idea. segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- and disappeared. And their daughter survived in England, that’s who they went to after the war. The Ritters had two sons, the younger of which was my brother’s age, the other one was a little bit older.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: And they had gone to Palestine before that, and they were in Palestine. The Ritters went -- went to them when the war was over. When we all left Shanghai they went to Palestine. segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And eventually made that into a luncheon area for other people. But especially the Ritters saw their sons in my brother and I.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: As I started school in Shanghai they were always interested in how I did, and so on.

segments.question: So they were sort of like another set of parents or at least some kind of relative in some way?
segments.answer: Yeah, well we were close to them --

segments.question: Close.
segments.answer: -- I didn’t consider them relatives, I think they considered us more their children --

segments.question: Yes, yes.

segments.question: When you first arrived and saw Shanghai and saw this strange port with all these small boats, big boats, whatever, what -- what did you think? Was it exciting to you?
segments.answer: Exciting and scary both.

segments.question: And scary, yeah.
segments.answer: Everything was so strange. First of all, Shanghai, the waterfront 1s called the Bund, which prior to World War II had these giant, beautiful buildings, high rise buildings right around, they look very impressive. But then you saw these coolies, these are the workman. When they took the heavy stuff and carried it on bamboo sticks, walking one man in front, one man behind on bamboo sticks, in a singsong voice so they kept their tread going so they moved smoothly. This was weird to see. Then you saw the rickshaws, where a man actually pulling a little wagon all along the street. And then the poverty, the beggars on the street, crippled to some degree, trying to beg stuff. And Mrs. Ritter had a sister who was in Shanghai already, they actually were there to welcome us. They said, well most of the refugees are moving into the Hongkew area. Hongkew was a part of Shanghai that had been devastated during the war between the Japanese This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. Many refugees, most refugees ended up there and started to rebuild the area. People were put into what was referred to as homes. One room per family, large rooms where people were living together. And everybody warned us against that, so this is where we didn’t want to go. So the first thing we did was go into a hotel on Bubbling Well Road and stayed there for awhile, well I stayed there while the adults went out shopping for a place to live.

segments.question: Now is this where you played “Troubles” with the staff?
segments.answer: This -- this is where --

segments.question: And what is that game?
segments.answer: Well, it’s -- the German name for it is Mensch Argere dich Nicht. I’m not quite sure what it is called in England, but it’s a board game.

I won every game, I don’t know if it was purposely or not, but it kept me busy, it kept me from running around. But looking at it back now, my parents left me as a nine year old kid in a strange hotel.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: But nothing happened, I’ve ha -- I had fun, people enjoyed having a little kid there. And these were not necessarily Chinese, these were Americans, British, French, all kinds of people.

segments.question: My goodness.
segments.answer: And the synagogue was there, it became sort of a museum, and we were able to go into it. And those things I recognized.

segments.answer: Lot of people did, and they were transported by trucks to the homes or other places in Hongkew.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: I’m trying to remember, I don’t know whether we went by -- h-how we got to that hotel. I imagine we went by cab, but I couldn’t tell --

segments.question: Not by rickshaw?
segments.answer: No, we used rickshaws later on, but I don’t believe we took rickshaws to the hotel, however I- my memory fails me on that one.

segments.question: Do you remember what the mood of everybody was? Were people very anxious? Could you -
segments.answer: No, I don’t think as a nine year old child I could --

segments.question: That you would -- yes.
segments.answer: -- detect that. I know that we -- the ship docked on the other side of the river, you know, Shanghai is along a river, and we took like a little ferry boat --

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: -- to the Custom House area where we came in, and on that ferry boat, there was somebody from the Jewish community, from Jewish committee in Shanghai who sort of clued us in a little bit. But what he clued us in 1s, he showed us the Garden bridge, the bridge going over the Suzhou creek on one side of which was the International Settlement under British control and the other side was already under Japanese control. And he told us that you have to walk across this This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection bridge, you can’t drive across it, that you have to show your papers to the Japanese guard, and the Chinese people that are crossing there always had to take off their hat and bow down to the Japanese. And somebody made s-some remark, well, what are we coming to here? It sounds as bad as what we’ve left behind. And that of course, is where the homes were, that’s where the most refugees began to live. But we, somehow or another didn’t go there. We ended up at this Burlington Hotel.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And as I say, I don’t recall how we got there.

segments.question: Do you remember being registered anywhere?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: No, you just walked in?
segments.answer: We just walked in. I bi -- I mean -- obviously we had to register at the hotel, but --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- not registered as --

segments.question: But not at any formal --
segments.answer: Formal [indecipherable]. I imagine we did, but I don’t remember any [indecipherable]

segments.question: So you don’t remember -- you didn’t have to carry papers or anything?
segments.answer: I didn’t. My parents had to --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- they had their German passports still, with the big J in it. And we as children were listed in that passport --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- we didn’t have our separate passport. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection

segments.question: You didn’t have your own. Ha -- do you remember how long you stayed in that hotel? Was it a couple of weeks, was it --
segments.answer: It wasn’t too long.

segments.question: A few da -- it wasn’t too --
segments.answer: Be -- maybe a week or two.

segments.question: Uh-huh. And then you moved to the French Concession, which was more south, closer to the harbor, I guess. Or not?
segments.answer: No, actually not, no --

segments.question: No?
segments.answer: -- it’s -- the French Concession stretched along, you know, mi-might say it’s parallel to the International Settlement. The French Concession had the nicer living quarters. Even today it still has --

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: -- the nicer living quarters. And what I do remember is like, the streetcars that could only go up to one point and then you had to take another streetcar on the other side. And there were trolley cars that were driven by electricity, but no tracks. So the electricity was different in the French area that it was in the in -- in the International Settlement.

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: When they got there, one guy jumped off the car, they took a running start, pulled the wires down, ran across the street and then hooked the wires back up on the other side. And that’s how you got from one end to the other. It wasn’t too far away because from there I was able to walk to school.

segments.question: Right. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: And school was in the International Settlement.

segments.question: It was in the International Settlement?
segments.answer: It was a Jewish school.

segments.question: Just called the Shanghai Jewish school, is that where you went?
segments.answer: The Shanghai Jewish school.

segments.question: And did you go there fairly quickly from when you ca -- you came in July --
segments.answer: No, we came in July of -- and they were overcrowded there, and I had a hard time -- my parents had a hard time getting us registered. Eventually we did, but by this time it was September, or October. I think it was after the Jewish holidays.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: The principal, he was called Reverend Brown. Course, was all British schooling, and my first day in school they had a dictation. I ac -- should go back a little bit to -- when I was being tutored in Liegnitz, I was also tutored in English.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: So for about half the year I had some English lessons. And that was my whole experience in English. Now I come into this class, it’s being taught in English, we have a dictation, where you write down everything. The teacher knows I -- where I came from, so she corrected every word I misspelled, which was practically every word. You’ve never seen so much red ink on one piece of paper. But it didn’t take long. They put me in a class a year younger than I was --

segments.question: They put you in second grade?
segments.answer: I guess it was second grade, I had not -- I don’t even remember for sure what grade, they called it form, the British school.

segments.question: Uh-huh. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: Form. But I was -- I mean, the kids in class were a year younger than I.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: And after a year I caught up enough to be put into my regular class.

segments.question: And was everything taught in English?
segments.answer: Everything was taught in English. But as a child, you pick this up very quickly. The other children were help -- the teachers were helpful. Some of the other kids were refugee kids that were there a little longer than I, they helped. I joined the Cub Scouts, right -- you know, about a year later.

segments.question: And your brother was in the Boy Scouts?
segments.answer: Boy Scouts, and --

segments.question: So your brother was in fifth grade, or sixth grade, something like -- whatever -- whatever the equivalent --
segments.answer: What -- I do -- I don’t remember what number --

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: -- it was, but he was obviously four years ahead of me, however, he only went to school for about a year and a half.

segments.question: And then he went to work.
segments.answer: And then he was sent to work.

segments.question: Right. So, are your parents learning English at all?
segments.answer: Very little, very --

segments.question: Very little. So you’re speaking German at home?
segments.answer: At ho -- home we spoke German, in school we spoke English. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection

segments.question: Spoke English. And is there a common language in Shanghai or 1s just -- English just one of them because there’s so many languages?
segments.answer: English was the main language that you were able to [indecipherable] get along with. Obviously it’s Chinese, but even Chinese wasn’t [indecipherable] I mean, the Shanghai dialect is quite different from Mandarin, which is the main language of China today. My brother picked up Chinese --

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: -- where he worked. I never did, other than a few words here and there, some which you -- curse words you learn very easily in every language. But my parents lived within this Jewish -- German Jewish community.

segments.question: In the French Concession.
segments.answer: In the French Concession, we had [indecipherable] contact with other people. My father tried to open a practice, he actually took an office for about a year or so in the International Settlement. But the refugees as a rule did not come to him because they didn’t have any money, the Chinese didn’t come to him. He had recommendation to two -- to two physicians, and they were very nice to us, they helped my father out, taught him something about [indecipherable] diseases. But all in all my father was not able to make a living from his practice. He tried all kinds of things. One time somebody offered him a job in the leprosy colony, my mother put her foot down on that. She said, that we don’t need.

segments.question: She thought he would catch it?
segments.answer: Leprosy is -- you know, has a bad name to it.

segments.question: Bad reputation. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: Very bad reputation. And -- but one time somebody was looking for my father and I said, well he’s in that hospital over there. And I said well come on, I’Il -- P’Il take you there. And I took off with these two complete strangers to show them where my father was. My mother was horrified. You know, you hear about kidnapping and all that kind of stuff. But I was perfectly at ease to do that. And we walked to school every day and I caught up fairly quickly with my class.

segments.question: So what was your father doing?
segments.answer: Sat around.

segments.question: Sat around.
segments.answer: Doing nothing. Became very depressed. Eventually these nine people decided to open up a little lunch room, you know? Noon time was the main meal that you ate in Europe. There were a lot of people there who didn’t know how to cook, pi -- single bachelors, what have you. They loved the lunch room, but inflation went -- was so rampant, that we didn’t make any money. We basically paid for our own food. And my father acted like a maitre d’, you know, welcoming people, seating them, etcetera. In between he still practiced a little bit. My mother did most of the cooking. The other men did the shopping, they used to go out and come back on the rickshaw with all the food. There wasn’t much refrigeration there, so you had to buy the food the same day that you were cooking it.

segments.question: Right, right.
segments.answer: And I don’t know for how many years that lasted, but it lasted for a little while. My mother also baked cakes for people. And what we loved is when one of the cakes didn’t come out right. Then --

segments.question: So you could have it.
segments.answer: -- that was not good enough to sell, but -- This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- good enough for us to eat.

segments.question: So she learned well enough from Marthe how to cook?
segments.answer: She -- she learned -- she became an excellent cook.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: But cooked everything in the German style. I mean --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- no Chinese food, per se. She took the Chinese vegetables, and somehow or another --

segments.question: Made them into German.
segments.answer: -- made it into German food, which is, of course, what everybody loved.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: She also adj -- when -- once we got our furniture, she got her sewing machine, and she started sewing for people. So she did -- whatever money we made, was made by her.

segments.question: Right. So your father must have been really demoralized by this.
segments.answer: Terribly demoralized.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And the end result of that was that my brother took on the job of being the head of the household.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: He began to speak English, he began to speak some Chinese. He was able to maneuver throughout the city, and one of these doctors that my father was referred to knew a machinist from Switzerland, and he suggested the Henry might get a job with him, which he did. But this This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection place was at the other end of town. It was -- I don’t know how long it took him, but it took him about an hour by bicycle to get there. And then he worked under the worst conditions.

segments.question: Was this Allensbach?
segments.answer: Alle -- yes.

segments.question: He wasn’t very nice to him either.
segments.answer: He was not very nice to Henry --

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: -- and Henry has never forgiven my parents for what they -- that they send him out like that. But they were desperate, my father especially was desperate. He didn’t see how things are going to go on, you know. How long is this war going to take?

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: So at 14, he worked -- he started to work full time.

segments.question: Right. Can I ask you, was this -- was this sort of typical of the problems that the refugees had, that the male in the family, the -- the adult male was not able to earn a living and the kids had to go out, or wa -- do you --
segments.answer: It was not -- it was typical in some instances.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: Doctors, lawyers -- lawyers had no way of --

segments.question: The professionals had nothing to do.
segments.answer: -- pro -- professionals.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: If you were a shoemaker --

segments.question: You ha -- This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: -- you did fine.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: If you did -- a watchmaker, you did fine.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: Talking about watchmaker, there was a watchmaker who we became friendly with later on, Flautto, he actually made watches and clocks from scratch. And when Roosevelt got re-elected in 1940, he send Roosevelt wa -- a little clock that he had made as a present, and got a sec -- thank you note. I became friendly with his son years later.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: So these are the people did very well, some people opened up little shops.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And also we must remember my father was in this -- by this time 50 some years old.

segments.question: Right, right, he wasn’t a young person.
segments.answer: He was not a young person any more. He tried to learn other trades, but that didn’t come easy to him. He was often taken advantage of, and we didn’t trust the banks. Some of the money we had was kept in either British pounds or American dollars, and then every time you needed some, you changed it into China’s currency.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: You didn’t do that too much because the inflation was so tremendous. So my father one time went and got some money in Chinese currency, on the Central Reserve Bank of China. He came home with that and Henry said, “Doctor, you got taken. Central Reserve Bank, that’s the bank of the Chinese puppet government under the Japanese [indecipherable] government. It’s not going to be worth much.” But shortly afterwards the Japanese took over China -- This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection

segments.question: And then it was worth more.
segments.answer: And then it became the currency to have. So where he thought he was taken he actually got ahead of everybody.

segments.question: Now when you first came, the Japanese controlled part of Hongkew, right?
segments.answer: They controlled all of Hongkew, actually.

segments.question: All of Hongkew.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: And -- and the International Settlement went up to a certain point, but that was not taken over by the Japanese, nor was the fre -- the rest of Shanghai --
segments.answer: Was taken over on December eighth.

segments.question: Yes, right.
segments.answer: At that --

segments.question: In 1941.
segments.answer: [indecipherable] in 1941.

segments.question: Right. But so --
segments.answer: But up until that point it was still separate.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: Had this separate government, they had the French government on one area which was like a French colony and --

segments.question: And then the British.
segments.answer: -- then the British were primarily in charge of the International Settlement.

segments.question: Was there an American [indecipherable] This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: There was an amer -- American presence there, too. There were American Marines at the -- they were actually stationed right across the street from our school. There were American Marine barracks.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: And then December seventh, which of course, because of the International Dateline, December eighth in Shanghai, the Japanese took over the rest of the town, the -- both the French and the British --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- at the International Settlement. Even prior to that, the allies knew that they can’t stay there forever, so many of the people living in Shanghai had already left back to the States, or France, wherever. Not France, because France was at war already. And there were two British -- two gunboats left in the harbor, a British and an American. And the Japanese started bombarding them. And the story goes that one surrendered and one went down, ship and all.

segments.question: Huh. Right.
segments.answer: But these were -- these are stories, I --

segments.question: You don’t know.
segments.answer: -- I don’t know these to be facts.

segments.question: Yeah, right.
segments.answer: What I do know is that December eighth was a Monday and I walked to school like always. We had by this time moved out of this building that we were sharing with our friends, to someplace else, further away from the waterfront. We didn’t hear the firing, we didn’t hear the bombardment. And we rode to work, which was in the Japanese area. I went to school, and the kids, did you hear the bombardment, the Japanese are taking over. We got called into the This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection auditorium, the principal told us about Pearl Harbor and that the Japanese at this moment are taking over the rest of the city. As he is speaking, we hear troops marching by the school, Japanese troops were marching by, occupying the Marine barracks across the street from us. And I still recall seeing the ja -- the American flag go down and the Japanese flag go up over the Marine barracks. And then they send us all home. By the time I ca -- came home, a kid a year or two younger than I had gotten home a few minutes before me, he told my parents and his parents all kinds of stories, they couldn't make heads or tails out of him, he was so nervous. I was the first one to tell them about Pearl Harbor and the Japanese taking over. In this time they worried sick about my brother.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: And he pedaled all the way through all this military takeover back home from where he was working. And after this my parents decided it’s time to move into Hongkew, into the area where all the refugees are living.

segments.question: Right. But let’s go back a little bit. In the -- when you’re living in the French Concession with these two couples and a single guy --
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: -- then all of those people decide they’re going to go to Hongkew. Wa --
segments.answer: They all decided to go to Hongkew and my mother still didn’t want to go to Hongkew.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: So they -- they --

segments.question: So you -- they left.
segments.answer: -- moved to Hongkew and we moved in with another family into a small apartment.

segments.question: Was that in kena -- ke -- This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: Yes, it started with a K.

segments.question: Ki -- ki -- K-1-n-e-a-r, Kinear. I don’t know how to pronounce it.
segments.answer: Kinear Road.

segments.question: Kinear Road.
segments.answer: I think yes, Kinear Road.

segments.question: Now, that was not in the French Concession.
segments.answer: No, that was --

segments.question: That was --
segments.answer: -- in the International Settlement.

segments.question: International Settlement.
segments.answer: But further, I guess, to the west, away from the harbor.

segments.question: Ha -- yes, and further away from Hongkew, it wasn’t [indecipherable] Hongkew.
segments.answer: Further away from Hongkew. A good ways away from Hongkew.

segments.question: Now, during this period, are you walking around Shanghai by yourself?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: You are, and it’s -- it’s -- it -- are your parents worried about you, given there’s supposed to be a lot of thievery and opium dens and God knows what there.
segments.answer: They must have been --

segments.question: But you went anyway.
segments.answer: -- but I di -- I’m -- I’m not aware of it. I mean, they had no choice. I mean, I walked to school by myself, and sometimes with friends.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: But we always -- it was always daytime, I didn’t walk around at night. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection

segments.question: At night. Did you see terrible things?
segments.answer: Yes. The Chinese were very poor and very dirty at that time. They had a child, an infant might die, they didn’t bury it. They wrapped it in newspaper and put it out on the sidewalk. So I see this on the sidewalk, I cross over on the other side of the street, not to be close to it. I see that. I see sometimes dogs na -- around these infant corpses.

segments.question: And could you see it was a corpse? A baby corpse? Because it wasn’t completely --
segments.answer: You could see that it was something covered.

segments.question: Something, uh-huh.
segments.answer: I hob -- I wasn’t curious enough to go close to it.

segments.question: Yeah, yeah.
segments.answer: I knew what it was.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: You saw people who were crippled on the street, begging, pushing a tin plate in front of them. You saw kids crying while the parents were poking them so they cry more, trying to beg. You hear and heard and saw thievery going on. There was the so-called hat-snatcher. You were sitting in the streetcar -- course, they were not air conditioned, was opened and the man had his hat on and just as the streetcar took off, somebody snatched the hat off.

segments.question: There was money in hats?
segments.answer: There was money in everything.

segments.question: I guess everything.
segments.answer: There was a law in the International Settlement, if somebody steals a loaf of bread and takes a bite out of it, he cannot be punished, cause it shows that he was hungry.

segments.question: Really? That’s interesting. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: And we just try to be careful, but the worst part was the diseases. You couldn’t -- everything had to be boiled.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: Water had to be boiled, you could not eat any raw food. Salads were basically out of the question. Sometimes my mother took some salad and put -- poured boiling water over it, well, if you put boiling water over a salad, it doesn’t taste too good any more.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: The Chinese had little shops where they boiled water and sold boiling water. And we would go there with a thermos, with tea leaves and a thermos, so get the boiling water, by the time we got home we had tea.

segments.question: Tea, yeah.
segments.answer: But they said, be sure you see the water boiling. It has to be bubbling. And that’s a -- these were big drums of water, so it took a long time for them to --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- really boil.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: The Chinese guy would like to sell it to you before he -- it was really boiling. We were told to be careful about that. You couldn’t walk barefoot. When the rains came, Shanghai flooded. Shanghai was basically at or below sea level, so you had no basements, no house had basements like we’re used to over here. When it flooded, h-how did we get around? Took a rickshaw, and we talked to the rickshaw pullee what you’re going to pay him to go to wherever you want to go, and then in the middle of the street he’d say no, I want more. He would just stop there, so you had to pay more to go on. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection

segments.question: But when it rained, it could be a foot of -- or more of water.
segments.answer: Yes, it could -- 1-1t was fairly deep, I -- let’s say a foot or so at times.

segments.question: Did you have boots?
segments.answer: Yes, but they were not big enough, so you just had to watch what you’re doing, and -- this water was, of course, terribly filthy --

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: -- and you could get all kinds of diseases. And we went through all sorts of illnesses. Typhoid, cholera. We got inoculated every six months against all these different illnesses.

segments.question: And where would you get inoculated? Would the -- would the Jewish Joint have a --
segments.answer: Well -- well, my father gave us the inoculation, I guess --

segments.question: He did?
segments.answer: -- I don’t know where he got the stuff from. But everybody got inoculated, the health department inoculated people on the street, but we were told not to get that, because you don’t know how clean those needles are.

segments.question: Oh boy, yeah.
segments.answer: So you -- when you got inoculated, you got a certificate to show that you have been inoculated. But with all that going on, people still got ill.

segments.question: Did you get ill during this early period?
segments.answer: Yes -- not the early period, I got ill --

segments.question: Later.
segments.answer: -- later on.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: The early period we did fairly well. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection

segments.question: Did you like being in shang -- I’m not -- talk -- bef -- before December eighth, se-seb -- before Pearl Harbor, did you like being there? Was it exciting, interesting?
segments.answer: It was exciting, it was interesting, 1t was an adventure. Sometimes they had gangs that would gang up on you. Of course [indecipherable] like anyplace.

segments.question: But this wasn’t because you were Jewish?
segments.answer: No, this was because I was white.

segments.question: I see. Were these Chinese or Japanese gangs?
segments.answer: Chi -- chi -- Chinese.

segments.question: Chinese gangs.
segments.answer: Chinese. And then the Russians, the Russian kids used to attack us, even in Hongkew later on. There was a lot of Russian people living there, and one time my father had a Russian person come up with one of his kids to -- something was wrong with him and he took care of him. And he was in part -- h-he was in some of these gangs. So if he was in the gang they told them -- he told the gang to leave me alone. I had my in with that.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: That’s -- that was always scary. You know, we didn’t have that much money on us, so if they want it, but --

segments.question: So they beat you up to try and get whatever money.
segments.answer: Whatever money you had. You gave them some money then you ran away.

segments.question: These were a lot of White Russians from Russia --
segments.answer: White Russians.

segments.question: -- who came after the revol -- revolution, right?
segments.answer: Yes. White Russians. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection

segments.answer: Yeah, there was a large Jewish Russian population.

segments.question: Uh-huh, yeah.
segments.answer: Very large. And some of them went to school with us, in the Shanghai Jewish school. But --

segments.question: Hi.
segments.answer: Hello.

segments.question: Tell me something. When -- when your brother Hans, or now Henry, was going to do work, was there a discussion or was he simply told by your father, you’re going to go out and -- to Allensbach factory and you’re gonna -- do -- do you know?
segments.answer: I don’t know.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: Basically speaking, I believe he was just told you have to go out there. I don’t think my father realized where he sent Henry to, and how bad it would be. I think my father should have checked it out instead of just taking somebody’s word for it.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And sending this little kid, 14 years old, out to nowhere. And he didn’t do that, he didn’t check it out. You know, today if you send your son, or daughter, your child someplace, you check it out, whether it’s a college, whether it’s a work situation. That, he didn’t do. They -- he was -- my father was so panicked. He didn’t know how he would feed his family. Here he comes from a upper middle class background as a physician. He had his dreams of sending his sons to same university he went to. Maybe they would go into his profession or something similar. All these dreams got shattered, and now he cannot even take care of them on a day to day basis. He was wotried how to feed us the next day. What will happen to us. So when this opportunity came around, he grabbed it and it’ll at least take care of us to some degree. Most of our quote unquote income consisted of selling what we had. We brought a lot of stuff along on this -- in this lift, and that’s what we lived on. It wasn’t until substantially later that we actually got charity. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. segments.question: So when your brother is working, it doesn’t contribute that much, because he’s not -- he’s not earning so much money’?
segments.answer: It doesn’t contribute -- 1-1t couldn't have contributed that much. You know, I wasn’t in on how much he’s actually paying in.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: But, you know, primarily selling our products, my mother’s work --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- was the main income.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: And I still went to school.

segments.question: Did Hans complain to you about the work at that -- at that time? Do you remember private conversations?
segments.answer: Yes, I -- I think more later on than at that time. I think I was too young to be privy to si -- this.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: Henry -- Pll call him Henry --

segments.question: All right, sure.
segments.answer: -- because that’s the way I’m used to it now, 1s a very private person, doesn’t open up very much. And four years at that age is a long --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- 1s a big age difference. But while I made friends and had fun, in and out of school, he didn’t. He worked many hours, he came home dead tired, slept, back to work, and I wasn’t aware of what he was going through at the time.

segments.answer: Six days a week.

segments.question: So he had -- he did have one day off.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: But -- mm-hm. Did you -- even though he didn’t say anything, did you realize it was hard on him in some -- do you recall a thi -- or are you just --
segments.answer: No, I don’t --

segments.question: You were too young.
segments.answer: -- I was too young.

segments.question: Yeah, yeah. When di -- when did you join the Cub Scouts and he joined the Boy Scouts, was it --
segments.answer: Right -- almost within the first year that we were there.

segments.question: Uh-huh. So did he stop when he was working? He wasn't part of 1t?
segments.answer: He was -- he stopped.

segments.question: He had to stop.
segments.answer: He stopped. Yeah, he stopped and his education stopped, to a --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- great extent.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: I went to school for many more years and lot of things that I was learning in school he never was taught, obviously he’s self taught since then.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: But I had a better education at that point. And -- but I wasn’t -- to answer your question honestly, I wasn't aware [inaudible] This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. segments.answer: You mean the relationship between my parents?

segments.question: Yes, was it diffit -- was it difficult?
segments.answer: It must have been very difficult.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: But again, a nine year old doesn’t see that.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: I know my parents loved to play cards, especially my father, loved to play German card game called Skat, and I would set up my cot and go to sleep while they were playing cards. I mean, I could sleep thr -- I slept through all of that.

segments.answer: And my parents, you know, played with us, we played cards and car -- board games and things like that. So we do -- did play together in that respect.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: I th -- think I saw more of what my mother went through, cooking and sewing, baking. And again my father was devastated that his wife had to support the family. And Henry was the man of the house, anything that came up to be discussed with the landlord, with this, with that.

segments.question: He did it.
segments.answer: He was involved in all these things.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: That went on all the time that we were in Shanghai. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word.
