segments.question: Were you afraid your father would commit suicide?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: You were?
segments.answer: Yes, there was a time when we were living out there on -- not Combare, what was the name of the street?

segments.question: Kinear?
segments.answer: Kinear Road.

segments.question: Kinear.
segments.answer: On Kinear Road, where I thought my father went up on the roof to kill himself. My father used to sit in a chair and fall asleep in middle of the day. Typical sign of depression.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: And that was one of the worst time for us, when we were on Kinear Road, very far away from all our friends. And that is of course where we lived when the Japanese took over, and shortly after that we moved to Hongkew. Whenever we moved, our apartment or room -- rooms, became smaller and smaller. My mother and I used make a chart and figure out how we would set up the furniture in the new place, and sometimes it was within an inch --

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: -- that we could squeeze something in, and what we couldn’t squeeze in, we sold. The move from Kinear Road into Hongkew was done on a push wagon, I mean it wasn’t a truck, a motorized truck , was hand pushed wagon all through the whole city of Shanghai.

segments.question: Cause it’s a big trip from Kinear Road into Hongkew.
segments.answer: It’s a very large trip. Th -- and then --

segments.question: Were these human beings that are pushing the -- This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: -- pulling the --
segments.answer: Pulling this cart.

segments.question: This isn’t a rickshaw, it’s bigger than a rickshaw.
segments.answer: No, it’s -- it’s bigger than a rickshaw, it’s two guys pushing it. And I guess one of us must have walked along with them. Yeah, Henry walked along with them. Of course it’s always Henry who had to do the dirty work. My mother and I went ahead. We might have taken the rickshaw, I don’t remember these things for f -- facts. So that when they came there, we were able to put everything --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- into the house.

segments.question: And they would move -- these guys would move the stuff into the apartment?
segments.answer: Into the apartment and we put them where they are. What I do remember is that I was also transferred to another school, from the Shanghai Jewish school, to the SJY A school, Shanghai Jewish Youth Association school, normally referred to as the Kadoorie School --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- because Sir Alec Kadoorie gave the money for that school. And you know, I was cutting up the last day in the other school. This one teacher didn’t believe that I would be moving, so he put me on detention, and the next day when we were actually moving into the other apartment, he happened to walk by and said, “Oh, you really were moving.” And yeah, we were friendly after that.

segments.question: Did you like the Kadoorie School better than this -- the British system in the --
segments.answer: Well, they were both the British system. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection

segments.question: They were both the British system.
segments.answer: The Kadoorie School was on the British system as well. It took me a little while to get used to the Kadoorie School, certain things were different, but not long and I was very familiar with everything there.

segments.question: Were there a lot of Jewish kids? In the Kadoorie School is all Jewish?
segments.answer: All Jewish.

segments.question: [indecipherable] this a Jewish school?
segments.answer: Well, this is Jewish refugee school.

segments.question: Uh-huh. As well as -- so was the other one.
segments.answer: The other one was not just refugees, it’s a Jewish school, th-the Russian Jewish kids there, the British Jewish kids, these are the people from India, and --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- that settled sh -- in Shanghai initially. I mean, they were both Jewish schools, and in the Kadoorie School, the allied citizens had to wear ya -- armbands because the Japanese had already taken over. So you had the British or American armbands and eventually these people were taken into POW camps, and only the refugee teachers remained.

segments.question: And the refugee kids.
segments.answer: And the refugee kids.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: There were basically none, other than refugee kids in that school. Mrs. Hartwich was the principal. Mr. Gassenheimer was my teacher, and he wer -- these teachers were excellent. They had no textbooks to give us, so -- there were no textbooks so they had to teach out of one book, This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection we had to write everything down. But we learned so much. I mean, I was not even 14 yet, this was 1941, I was 11 - 12. [indecipherable]

segments.question: So this is before your Bar Mitzvah.
segments.answer: Before my Bar Mitzvah. And we learned geometry, algebra, everything.

segments.question: Mm.
segments.answer: When many years later I decided to take some night courses in Montgomery College here, I took math and it was all a repeat, it was all what I had learned as a 12 year old kid. Gassenheimer was ex -- a fantastic teacher. They were trying to teach us so many things all at one time. I mean, everything was taught in English, even though they were refugee teachers, they were all taught in English. We -- being a Jewish school, we had Hebrew classes. Being in China, we had some Chinese classes. Being under Japanese control, Japanese classes.

segments.question: Japanese classes.
segments.answer: And Mrs. Hartwich thought that we should also learn French. Now this wasn’t one year of this and one year of that, these were all --

segments.question: All together.
segments.answer: -- taught simultaneously. The end result 1s that we didn’t learn anything to hold onto, a word here and a word there 1s all that I remember. English and German is what remained because we still spoke German at home. When we kids played, it was a mixture, we spoke both English and German interchangeably, but we had a good time as kids. There were no air raids --

segments.question: No?
segments.answer: -- going on, none at all. We didn’t have --

segments.question: That’s not until very late. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: That’s -- that much later. That doesn’t come about until Okinawa fell. You hav -- year or so later I was Bar Mitzvah and you had to pay tuition at that school, and when my Bar Mitzvah came about, Mrs. Hartwich came up to my parents, we usually don’t give Bar Mitzvah presents, but we like Ernest -- I don’t know what they called me, er -- they didn’t call me Ernie at that time. Anyhow, you don’t have to pay any more tuition.

segments.question: So they had to pay before?
segments.answer: Be -- we -- everybody had to pay, and this was my Bar Mitzvah present from --

segments.question: That’s lovely.
segments.answer: It was very lovely.

segments.question: So you made a big impression.
segments.answer: I obviously did very well. I --

segments.question: And you liked it. You liked it a lot.
segments.answer: I -- I liked it. I was -- I mean, math was my forte. I was considered the best math student in the school, not in the class, in the school.

segments.question: In the school.
segments.answer: We were -- eventually kids dropped out as they went to work, so the last year there we were 12 students in my class, six boys and six girls. We sat at a long table, the girls on one side, the guys on the other, teacher at the head. And I was the best math, it was a fellow by the name of Hans Eberstark who was the best all around student. He -- he was -- is a genius. He eventually -- his hobby was to go to the library and learn the dictionary by heart. But he was also a lot of fun. He went along with everybody with their jokes. He eventually started working for the United Nations in Switzerland, and although I don’t know these for facts, as things I’ve heard, he helped This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection write the Constitution for some of the new African nations, and as an interpreter for United Nations. We also had theater that we put up in school.

segments.question: Were you involved in that theater?
segments.answer: I was involved in it.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: I was in -- we did the part of Shakespeare, “Midsummer Night’s Dream.” I was Puck --

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: -- in “Midsummer Night’s Dream.” We also presented something in Japanese, where the Japanese paper came by and took a picture of us --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- sitting on the stage there. Course we learned it by heart, I have no idea what I was actually saying. The --

segments.question: But you were saying it in English?
segments.answer: No, on --

segments.question: Shakespeare --
segments.answer: The Shakespeare in English.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Yeah, but the Japanese play was in Japanese.

segments.question: Ah-ha, right. So they never told you what you were saying?
segments.answer: Well, they did, but --

segments.question: It didn’t --
segments.answer: -- it didn’t really matter that much. But we had -- the class had a great time, the 12 of us putting up these plays. We were 13 - 14 years old. No, not quite 14. But we really had a This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection wonderful time there. And eventually my parents decided that I sh -- finished that school as much -- far as I could go, that I should go to work. In the meantime my brother had -- was able to convince my parents at that place where he was working was not right, and through some acquaintances he found another place, working for a Korean company that made lathe, and drilling machines and so on, where he was able to get a job for me. So I became an apprentice in this machine factory under my brother, in a way. The factory had a small department where the - we made all the little parts, little screws, pins, what have you. And we were about half a dozen refugees working in there, including a Mr. Lawrence who was a foreman. And I worked there, and between my brother and I, we finally made a little bit more money than we were spending each day.

segments.question: So how old are you then? You --
F -- so this -- this is what, s-six or eight months after your Bar Mitzvah? No, yo -- it’s longer, it’s a year afterwards.
segments.answer: A year afterwards.

segments.question: This is 1943, before the announcement for the ghetto.
segments.answer: No, no.

segments.question: No.
segments.answer: [indecipherable] the announcement of the ghetto was in 1943.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: The announcement of the ghetto came while I was still in school.

segments.question: I see. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: And I remember at that point, I mean we read the announcement, we read the borders that there were, and we thought -- I thought we were okay. We were on the Seward Road, that’s where the line was.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: But the line went down the middle of the street, and we were on the wrong side --

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: -- of the street, and we had to move. Well, one of the girls that I was talking to about that, she thought they would have to move and she was on the correct side of the street.

segments.question: On the correct side.
segments.answer: So we had to move, and now to find a place to live was very difficult. See, in the ghetto, nobody had to move out. The Chinese people didn’t have to move out. You had to be in there within 90 days. Couldn’t -- it was very hard to find anything until the Jewish organization bought a part of a school and converted that school into small rooms and a few large halls. And you had to pay -- I forgot what they call it, key money or something like that, to be able to have one of these rooms. And my father had to sell his microscope so that he could have the money for us to move in there. So four of us moved into a room in the school. And it was very short distance to the school for me to walk there. The school was actually outside the district.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: However, the Japanese basically like kids and let us go to school. We have --

segments.question: Did you have to get a pass to go?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: And did you have to get it from this guy, Ghoya?
segments.answer: Yes. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection

segments.question: Was that terrible?
segments.answer: Well, it wasn’t so terrible as a kid because I -- I don’t think we ne -- actually needed it then, but when I went to work, where I worked was outside.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: And we had to get it from Ghoya, and that was terrible because it had to be renewed every month, and sometimes you stood in line for a month to get the renewal. So you stood outside there in every kind of weather, waiting for him to show up, then he showed up and gave a few renewals, gave a lot of rejections. Yeah, in summer it was hot with the sun beating down on you, then you went inside and scare -- you were scared, trying to get in front of this man who had such power over you. Initially some of the people decided not to follow -- not to move into the district, so they were thrown into jail for a week. Didn’t think a week’s imprisonment was so bad, but these cells were infected. They came out and died like flies once they came out. And that went on for the rest of the time.

segments.question: Was Ghoya the main person that you had to get -- wasn’t there somebody else called Okura?
segments.answer: Okura was actually Ghoya’s superior.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: But Okura wasn’t personally involved that much with us.

segments.question: But Ghoya was.
segments.answer: Ghoya was, he had a refugee man being his secretary, doing all the paperwork, but I don’t recall his name. But when Ghoya eventually got -- was out of it, this man just did every [indecipherable] just took care of everyone. He was very fine person. But Ghoya was terrible, it’s a -- Ghoya considered himself king of the Jews.

segments.question: It -- this was his own attribution for himself? This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: Yes. He thought he was doing us all a favor.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: Our sports activities were mainly playing soccer and he used to come out to the soccer field, where we had to parade past him, just like you parade past a king, and view him. And everything was fine and then the next morning for whatever reason, something he didn’t like, he threw the people in charge of the game into jail for a few days.

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: They never knew how he would a -- react on anything. He used to hit people for no reason whatsoever. And again, the kids he mainly left alone. I’m talking about the adults.

segments.question: Uh-huh. Did you ever see that? Did you ever see him hitting somebody [indecipherable]
segments.answer: No, but my father got -- he said he got hit on the hand, just like this, and he said, “I felt that for hours.” It was just [indecipherable]. And you know, the thing -- you were in such small quarters, everybody was on top of each other, slightest thing and people got into fights and arguments. The refugee communit -- community started their own -- what did they call it? Like a court system, so it didn’t have to go to the Japanese authorities. So you try to settle things outside of them. In the meantime, things got a little better for us because my father got a job with the -- with the hip -- not the hospital, but the -- well, with the hospital, yeah, yeah.

segments.question: Was it the free clinic?
segments.answer: The free clinic --

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: -- actually he got the job with the free clinic.

segments.question: Mm-hm. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: And with him getting a job in the free clinic, my brother and I working, we finally were able to make ends meet. In the meantime we had gotten onto charity. And before you could accept charity, they community send a committee up to your house, you know, places where you live, to make sure you had nothing left to sell, which was very demoralizing. But we got one hot meal a day, which was sort of a stew. My parents used to dig out the small pieces of meat there was, and gave it to Henry and I. My father lost over 50 pounds.

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: Was -- basically both of them were skin and bones, trying to keep us going.

segments.question: And did you guys lose weight? Did you lose a lot weight [indecipherable]
segments.answer: No, us kids, we didn’t, but you know --

segments.question: Were you hungry?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: You don’t remember being hungry”?
segments.answer: I -- I -- I was not hungry, my -- but my parents saw to it that I was not hungry.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: Henry was not hungry.

segments.question: And when the three of you were working, did your mother stop doing all this baking that she was doing, and sewing?
segments.answer: Yeah, she actually stopped that when we moved into the --

segments.question: She did?
segments.answer: -- into Hongkew, because she had no facilities there to do all that.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: So, I -- This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection

segments.question: But she still had her sewing machine? Or not?
segments.answer: She still had her sewing machine.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: Oh -- to the very end. When we finally -- the war is over and we made contact with her brother in Baltimore, things happened very rapidly and she said, should I bring my sewing machine or not, and we -- it never got to [indecipherable] anyhow, we sold it in Shanghai.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: And then she was sorry she didn’t bring it with her. But -- was going to say something else.

segments.question: We were talking about [indecipherable] meals and stuff.
segments.answer: Oh, no I was going to ta -- at this time is when I had my Bar Mitzvah.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: Which was basically a low point in our life, as financial is concerned. And my parents tried to make the Bar Mitzvah pretty nice. The cantor that we had used to be an opera singer in Europe. I can still see him, he looked like Pavarotti standing there in front of me, singing to me. It was done very beautifully. Our neighbors had a little haberdashery store and he came up to my mother a month or so ahead of time to loan him one of my shirts, he wants to make one for somebody, well he made a nice shirt for me. But what my mother had not realized, she gave him one that I'd -- I’d slightly outgrown. So the sleeves came up to here, and he had to attach something. That was my big present, was my shirt.

segments.question: Your new shirt.
segments.answer: And my Bar Mitzvah party consisted of coffee and cake. The rabbi came, my teacher came. And Gassenheimer was my teacher, the Hebrew teacher in our school --

segments.question: Was Gassenheimer? This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: No, was not Gassenheimer.

segments.question: No. Right.
segments.answer: Was a Mr. we -- Webber, I believe. He was teaching everybody but he was going into a lot of details.

segments.question: Uh-huh, right.
segments.answer: Gassenheimer was not so Orthodox. It was easier with him, and I took lessons from him and that went very well.

segments.question: How long did it take you to learn your Haftorah and learn the ceremony for your Bar Mitzvah?
segments.answer: Very short period of time.

segments.question: Like what, a month?
segments.answer: Two months maybe.

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: Two th -- two, three months, something like that. But --

segments.question: So you were quick?
segments.answer: Well, it wasn’t that so much, my birthday is December second.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: So when I approached Mr. Gassenheimer back in August sometime, he said, “Oh, December, we got plenty of time.” And first day back at school in sep -- early September, he calls me, he says, “I just looked it up, your Bar Mitzvah by the Jewish calendar is actually November 14". We’re talking a lot sooner, we really have to get onto it.” So we got onto it fairly rapidly. I don’t have a voice to sing, so I was just reading everything, and did fine. Everything went off pretty well, I did okay.

segments.question: Ha -- you had learned Hebrew before, so --
segments.answer: Oh yes.

segments.question: -- you knew --
segments.answer: I mean, I had ler -- started to learn Hebrew back in Germany.

segments.question: Right, in Germany, right.
segments.answer: I could read Hebrew, couldn’t speak it as a language -- This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- but, you know, I could read the Hebrew prayer books, and knew some of the translations, but basically just reading it was no problem for me.

segments.question: Did you have to give some sort of a speech, which is what they do in this country, I don’t know whether they do --
segments.answer: No, I didn't --

segments.question: No?
segments.answer: -- I didn’t do any speech.

segments.question: [indecipherable] speeches.
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: So where did it occur?
segments.answer: In the school.

segments.question: In the school.
segments.answer: The school is where we also had services.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: In the main school auditorium, that’s where we had services, we had youth services there to, where the kids from school did all the parts and I one time was the quote unquote rabbi --

segments.question: Oh yes?
segments.answer: -- had a little talk on the subject, the Torah subject of the day. So that’s where it was held.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: You know, it was very nice, and --

segments.question: And where was the coffee and the --
segments.answer: At -- at our home. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection

segments.question: At the ho -- at the si -- in this little room?
segments.answer: That’s -- in that little apartment. This was before we moved into the SACRA --

segments.question: Uh-huh, I see.
segments.answer: -- this was when we were on East Seward Road.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- so we actually had two rooms.

segments.question: Uh-huh, so it was bigger.
segments.answer: Bigger, and you know, we didn’t have that many people, maybe half a dozen people that came over.

segments.question: And did you drink coffee, or was there something else for kids?
segments.answer: Oh it -- I did drink coffee, but 1t probably was milk, or something like that.

segments.question: Uh-huh, uh-huh.
segments.answer: Don’t remember that much.

segments.question: Besides the communal lunches you were getting for nothing.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: And you were going to the --
segments.answer: The communal lunches really came about later, when we were in the SACRA building.

segments.question: Right, but when you were in East Seward, you were not.
segments.answer: We were not.

segments.question: So what -- all of this time, what -- what are you eating? Are you eating three meals a day, or would you not even call it three meals a day?
segments.answer: Yes, we were eating three meals a day --

segments.question: Uh-huh. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: -- and usually the noon meal was the main meal.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: I mean, we didn’t have cereal, per se, that I recall.

segments.question: So what was breakfast like?
segments.answer: It was a light breakfast, some bread and butter and jelly, what have you. And I --

segments.question: And did your mother have to -- she had to buy food every day.
segments.answer: She went to buy food daily --

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: -- because of there was no refrigeration.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And she managed very well to do that.

segments.question: And at night it was also very small.
segments.answer: Very small, like a little supper. But I can’t honestly tell you what we were eating. I’m -- the only thing I remember 1s that my mother made -- you know --

segments.question: She baked.
segments.answer: -- she did -- changed everything into German cooking. You know, people hear that I was living in Shanghai, they think of me eating Chinese food. No, we didn’t do that, we ate German food. Many of the things we never heard of before. Some of it came through the Russians, there’s kasha.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: I remember that, and I hated it. But that --

segments.question: You hated it? This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: [hated it, I won’t touch it now. But kasha was our cereal, and that was served to us. And other things, for example, Passover came about, the rabbi announced this particular cereal type of food is good for Passover, for those people who were Orthodox.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: Made up our own rules. Kasha, there was -- we drank a lot of tea, ate a dra -- ate a lot of rice, and for a long time after I came to the United States, I hardly touched tea or rice. Since then I’ve been accustomed to it more.

segments.question: Did you ever eat Chinese food in Shanghai?
segments.answer: Yes, when -- when we had got our visa to come to the States, we went out to a quote unquote Chinese restaurant.

segments.question: Really? That was the first time?
segments.answer: A nice Chinese place. Not the first time, it -- but I remember that time because we -- we ri --

segments.question: Was it good? Did you like it?
segments.answer: Yeah, we liked it. One time earlier, one of these doctors that my father had been referred to, took us to a really fancy Chinese restaurant with several courses came in -- coming in. But I was very little at that time, I didn’t appreciate all of it, but it rel -- 1t can be nice.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: But most of the time it was make do with what was available.

segments.question: Right. It wasn’t an easy time, was it?
segments.answer: No, it was not. I -- I mean, again, as a child you don’t know these things, but for my parents it must have been terrible, not knowing how they’re going to feed us the next day.

segments.question: Right. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: How are they going to pay for the food? And tha -- you know, once we moved into the SACRA, it’s there that we applied and eventually got charity. And I remember the people coming in, looking over to see --

segments.question: To make sure that you had nothing to sell.
segments.answer: To make sure there was nothing to sell. And then we got this one hot meal a day, which was big pot of stew.

segments.question: And did they bring that to your apartment, or did you have to go --
segments.answer: Well, they brought it in a cart, and then they --

segments.question: And they’d ladled it.
segments.answer: Ladled it out. And we had a pot they ladled it in --

segments.question: Right, right.
segments.answer: -- and then my parents tried to give us as much meat as possible.

segments.question: And the other two meals they had to be responsible for getting them to you?
segments.answer: Yes. And one was some sort of kasha or whatever that was.

segments.question: So what did you drink in the course of the day, because it had to be extremely hot at certain times of the year, right? I mean, you would need to drink a lot, right?
segments.answer: We need to drink a lot, we drank hot water.

segments.question: You drank hot water.
segments.answer: Because when we went to work, my brother and I went to work, and our mother took -- made some sandwich for us, but we couldn’t take anything to drink with us, and whatever we drank had to be boiled. So we had to see that it 1s boiled, and then we drank hot water. Hot water and sort of dry bread was our lunch. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection

segments.question: But what happens with the communal meal, if the communal meal is the middle of the day, and the two of you were working, what happens?
segments.answer: My parents kept it for the evening, and then reheat it.

segments.question: So you -- you would have it in the evening. And did your father work all day long once you got into --
segments.answer: No, it was a while before he --

segments.question: Awhile before --
segments.answer: -- got that.

segments.question: So you were working with your brother before your father got to --
segments.answer: Oh yes, and my father was still practice once in awhile, and then everybody had to leave that one room that we lived in when he had a patient in there.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: Other times when it wasn’t such a personal examination, I assisted him in some things. We had like a little balc -- not a balcony, like a walk around the room outside where we fired up the, what we called the Chinese oven, which was a hibach -- hibachi. Over here when we do the hibachi it’s a lot of fun, over there, that was the way to go. Had to buy charcoal to do it, and when charcoal became too expensive, we bought powdered coal, which we mixed with water, and made into little coal balls to heat up. Our hands were black as --

segments.question: Black.
segments.answer: -- oh, it was terrible. And there was one woman in -- w-we were quite a few people in this building, couldn’t tell you the quantity. The one woman worked in a restaurant. She used to come home and bring the coffee grounds from the restaurant. Anybody has a fire going, you can- they can share with me a cup of coffee. So my mother had -- loved coffee, she missed coffee This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection more than anything else. So she had the fire going and drank the coffee when it was going through the grounds a second time. And it’s -- and there also were -- we got bombed out. In 19 --

segments.question: But that’s later --
segments.answer: That’s later, okay --

segments.question: -- let -- let -- let me just ask you a couple of things. Now, did I just forget my question.
segments.answer: We’re talking about food, and -- we’re talking about the communal kitchen stuff that came in.

segments.question: Ah, this is what I wanted to know. Does your -- does your father’s mood, as you see it now, get better when he starts to work and the three of you are working? Do you see a difference?
segments.answer: When my father got the job in the clinic, his mood began to change.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: His mood began to change, and made all the difference in the world then. And I remember, you know, you couldn’t deal in American currency on -- on open market, but Chinese currency had no value. So when we finally were able to come to a point where we could buy some American dollars, 1t was a big point because that was a turning point. This month we actually made more than we spent.

segments.question: I see, because it was worth more.
segments.answer: It was [indecipherable] we were able to buy some dollars on the black market, and that’s what we put aside.

segments.question: Now, before you meet -- they don’t actually call it a ghetto, they say the designated area for stateless refugees, right?
segments.answer: Exactly.

segments.question: So it’s actually for all of you who would come after ’37, am I correct?
segments.answer: Correct. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection

segments.question: So it’s mainly Austrian and German refugees.
segments.answer: Correct.

segments.question: Oh -- as well -- and y --
segments.answer: Some Polish also.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: I don’t know ho -- the Polish -- w-we -- they were in there, but it’s primarily the German and Austrian refugees.

segments.question: Right. Before you go in there, there’s a lot going on in Europe.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: A lot of murdering of Jews.
segments.answer: We didn’t know that.

segments.question: Di -- you didn’t know, you hear nothing.
segments.answer: We know that they are being put into concentration camps.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: My grandmother, my mother’s mother was still in Breslau. She was up in age when we were getting ready to leave, and my aunt, who was quite wealthy, had paid in an old age home for the rest of her life, so she didn’t have to worry about money. My mother asked her to come with us to Shanghai, she said, “Look, you guys going to have a hard time in Shanghai, why should I be along? Who would do anything to a -- an old woman like me. I’m taken care of over here.” So we corresponded with my grandmother all the time we were there, and one time a letter comes back, moved, address unknown. And we knew that meant concentration camp. And I recall seeing my mother in tears when she got that.

segments.question: Mm-hm. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: When we got that notification. Now, what concentration camp meant, that it was death camps, we were unaware of. As it turned out, my grandmother was taken to Theresienstadt, and from what we understand, she died there.

segments.question: Do you think that your parents knew more than you and Hans knew?
segments.answer: No, I don’t.

segments.question: You don’t?
segments.answer: I don’t think.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: I don’t think anybody knew this.

segments.question: Right. So people didn’t have radios, they didn’t have a way of --
segments.answer: Well we had radios.

segments.question: You did. But you couldn’t get -- you -- you couldn’t go far enough to get --
segments.answer: But the radios didn’t announce it.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: The Russian radio had a German program on it. See, Russia was not at war with Japan.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: So the Russians were free, and the Russians reported very accurately what went on on the European frontier. Now, we heard, you know, about the landing in Normandy and all that, almost at the same time as you would have heard over here. But we didn’t hear anything about the Japanese war.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: And one time we -- it came through about Okinawa and we looked on a map and we saw where Okinawa was, and we said to ourselves, God, that isn’t so far away from us any more. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection And then shortly after that, that bombing off Shanghai began. So once a island like Okinawa, comparatively close to the Chinese mainland, was captured, planes flew from there, and did their missions from there.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: But most of the bombing of Shanghai occurred in the outskirts.

segments.question: Right. Do you think any -- do you think that the majority of refugees, the stateless refugees in Hongkew knew nothing?
segments.answer: Of the death camps? I don’t believe they did.

segments.question: Until after the war.
segments.answer: Until after the war.

segments.question: Right. W-When you saw the notice, or all of you saw the notice to go into the designated area, which was February °43, and you have to be in there by May.
segments.answer: May.

segments.question: Am I correct?
segments.answer: February 18" -- May 18".

segments.question: February 18 -- yes. Were you worried about having to go in there, or did you think that the Japanese wouldn’t do anyth -- I mean what -- what -- what was the sensation about the Japanese?
segments.answer: Well, we were worried. I mean, the Japanese were in control there, and Germans were their buddy buddies.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: We had no idea what was going on in Germany, but we realized this is an imprisonment of sorts.

segments.question: Yes. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: And only of sorts, because usually when you are a prisoner, they feed you.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: Here we had to feed ourselves.

segments.question: Selves, right.
segments.answer: And, you know, primarily, the first thing is trying to find the place to live.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: I mean, just imagine yourself at -- you decide to move and you have 90 days to do it. So it -- it’s not easy to find a place under the best of circumstances, and here, all of a sudden, all these people trying to move in. Many people switched homes with the Chinese. They took their fancy house, something like as nice as this one and traded it for a hovel.

segments.question: So there were some people who did very well in Shanghai, as far as you can tell?
segments.answer: You mean among the refugees?

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Very well is exaggerating it a bit.

segments.question: Uh-huh, okay.
segments.answer: They did well. They made more money than they spent. That’s considered doing well. There were some -- there was one family from Liegnitz, one -- a couple actually, they didn’t have any children. They came with their parents. And his father was not Jewish, so he didn’t have to move into the ghetto. The younger couple got a little place in the ghetto, but they were all watchmakers. His father employed him, and he was able to work with his father and live outside the ghetto.

segments.question: Right. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: They did work quite well. This Mr. Schwartz who lived next door to us, he the one that made the shirt for me, he had a store across the street, and he seemed to do all right. And a lot of the people who were handymen, plumbers, electricians, what have you, they did fairly well.

segments.question: But they’re working with the Jewish refugees, right, who don’t seem to have a lot of money. So how are these other people, even though they have the skills, how were they making money’? Do you understand it?
segments.answer: Well, we all had a little bit of money s -- coming from somewhere.

segments.question: Uh-huh. Somewhere.
segments.answer: I mean, you had to have a plumber, you needed a plumber.

segments.question: Right, right.
segments.answer: I am not sure how these things --

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: -- all came together again. You couldn’t see that.

segments.question: And who did you rent from? When you rented this little room.
segments.answer: Well the room in the SACRA was of course, the SACRA organization.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: It stood for something.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: Shanghai soma -- something or another. Prior to that, a Chinese ow-owned the house.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: And the --

segments.question: In Seward, when you were in east --
segments.answer: On East Seward Road. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: And he had a sh-shop downstairs and rented out the upstairs. And once the war was over, and we moved back a block away on East Seward Road, the same thing occurred. Somebody had a s- store downstairs and rented out the upstairs.

segments.question: All right, let me ask you about hygiene.
segments.answer: Yes?

segments.question: You probably didn’t have a toilet inside.
segments.answer: Yeah, we did.

segments.question: You did?
segments.answer: We did have --

segments.question: Throughout?
segments.answer: Throughout, that’s one thing we insisted on, WC in the --

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: -- meaning water closet, yes.

segments.question: So that’s unusual?
segments.answer: Well, it wasn’t too unusual, but it wasn’t unusual not to have it. But we had it, we did not have to have an outhouse.

segments.question: So you didn’t have to have one of these what they called the honey buckets?
segments.answer: Nope, we didn’t have to have a honey bucket.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: Thank God.

segments.question: Wa-Was that the main given by the refugees, a honey bucket?
segments.answer: I would imagine so. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection

segments.question: You imagine so. Because that, I’m sure, was very uncomfortable.
segments.answer: Well, but, you know, when we walked to work, or walked to school --

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: -- we would see these Chinese people cleaning out their honey buckets --

segments.question: Buckets.
segments.answer: -- in the middle of the street.

segments.question: And there would be people who would come, and you would dump the --
segments.answer: They du -- come in one of these carts, they would dump it in, and then they would take it out in the field and use it as fertilizer.

segments.question: As fertilizer.
segments.answer: That’s another reason why you had such --

segments.question: So did Shanghai stink?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Was it a lot of s -- awful smells?
segments.answer: Awful smells, especially -- yeah. Not in the French Concession, yeah, the fancy residential area, but in the Hongkew area, it stank. I mean literally, it was terrible. And the people on the boats, they threw their waste into the water.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: Now that’s the same water that then came out of your faucet.

segments.question: So that’s why you had to boil it.
segments.answer: Yeah, boil it.

segments.question: And even boiling, I would imagine, didn’t clean everything.
segments.answer: Well, they well -- that did go through some cleansing pro -- This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: -- process before it got there, but the bacteria of course, all came straight through.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And sometimes people thought that certain filters would help it or -- they tried it and they --

segments.question: It didn’t.
segments.answer: It didn’t. And we got all kinds of illnesses. Typhoid, typhus.

segments.question: Did your parents ever get sick?
segments.answer: Oh yeah. My parents got sick, I got very sick.

segments.question: You got very sick at the end.
segments.answer: I had [indecipherable]

segments.question: And so did your brother --
segments.answer: -- war was actually over.

segments.question: -- right?
segments.answer: My brother got sick --

segments.question: Something --
segments.answer: -- he had got sick --

segments.question: Bacterial dysentery or something like that?
segments.answer: Bacterial dysentery in there at one point. But wa -- I -- I had either typhus or typhoid, I never can keep it straight, whatever comes from lice.

segments.question: And your parents?
segments.answer: My father had some bacterial disease, my mother had something else. Everybody got sick all the time.

segments.question: And so they got sick, and then they got over it and then they got sick. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. segments.answer: Sick, and over it. Some things were not so serious as others.

segments.question: Let me ask you this, when you look back -- I’m sure at this age you wouldn’t have seen it, but when you look back and think about when you move into the designated area, wh-where people are now calling the ghetto.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: Maybe you ca -- did you call it the ghetto then?
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: You did.
segments.answer: But -- yeah, I -- yeah.

segments.question: So your mother stops doing cer -- the things that she was doing because all the boys in the family, the men are working, right?
segments.answer: Well, the -- yeah, bo -- my father didn’t start working until --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- some time after that.

segments.question: But at a certain point he does.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: And she stops. Now do you --
segments.answer: She di -- she did -- she continued doing --

segments.question: Oh, she did?
segments.answer: -- something. I mean, we didn -- we didn’t have the lunchroom any more.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: That stopped when we moved away from rue Ratard. I think she still did some of the sewing. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. segments.question: Okay, then my question is not -- I’I] tell you what I was going to ask you. I thought that possibly she pulled back from all these things so that your father could feel even s -- even stronger, but maybe --
segments.answer: No, you know, that was not the case.

segments.question: No.
segments.answer: I’m not sure at this point how the money that we needed to have came about.

segments.question: Uh-huh, right.
segments.answer: Mostly it came about from selling things. My father’s microscope, my mother’s fur coat, and this, that, the other.

segments.question: Right, right.
segments.answer: [indecipherable] more and more.

segments.question: Did you hate going to work?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: You didn’t resent it?
segments.answer: No. I looked forward to it, you know.

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: You get out of school, you get to work, I can do someth -- accomplish something.

segments.question: But you loved school.
segments.answer: I loved school, and I --

segments.question: And you loved the work?
segments.answer: -- I basically loved work, but I was an apprentice, I didn’t like it when they had me cleaning up.

segments.question: I see. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection
segments.answer: I wanted to get onto the machinery, learn how to use the machinery.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: The Korean who owned the company, he didn’t want to see me on the machinery, he wanted me to clean here, clean there.

segments.question: Clean --
segments.answer: This department where we made all the small parts was sort of a showplace for him.

segments.question: Uh-huh.

segments.question: Ernie, you were talking about the bombing and your parents --
segments.answer: My parents were outside --

segments.question: Outside.
segments.answer: -- and the building there, it was a brick building and a fairly sturdy building, so where they stood wer -- did not come down, the ceiling did not come down. And my mother at first thought that there’s somebody lying in front of our door that she couldn’t open it, because the air pressure was so strong from the bombs falling. But finally she was able to open it, and after a few seconds, actually, I guess, I was able to yell I’m here, and push stuff away from me and jumped out into their arms. No sooner was that done than a call came from my father to help here and help there because there were -- a lot of people were wounded, and quite few had died. But my brother was at work, and somebody was telling him at the wor -- and he decided to come home when he realized where the bombing had occurred. So he started running home, it was a good 45 minute walk. And on the way he met people, he said -- he asked, what about the SACRA building, and people just, oh, everybody got killed in the SACRA building. It was not til he was about a block or two away that he met somebody who knew us, and he said, don’t worry, your -- your family is fine. Now, I still had a temperature from the flu or whatever I had, so I was lying outside on a rug, trying to stay calm. And my mother was with me when he came. We couldn't find my father, he was being called from one end to the other. And then they said, well we all have to move into this school. And my mother said, I don’t want to move into the school with all these people. So we cleaned up our room a little bit --

segments.answer: -- and stayed there for the first night. You could see the stars coming through the ceiling. And during the night a fire broke up somewhere in this complex, was actually two buildings. Well, the next morning we all decided we better move into the school. So we grabbed -- each one grabbed a mattress and walked those three blocks to the school. The classrooms were made empty, and you put one mattress next to the other, man, woman, child. And that’s where we stayed. But neither Henry nor I decided to go back to work. We refused to go back to work.

segments.question: You refused?
segments.answer: We were too scared. And this was July 17". Shortly afterwards the war was over. The way we found out the war was over, on August 10" is my mother’s birthday. We woke up in the morning, we heard bombs falling. My father said, here’s some -- they’re saluting you to your birthday. And then at night, wi -- what was always black out, all of a sudden the lights went on. There’s Mrs. Hartwich, the principal in her nightgown. I just heard over the shortwave that the Japanese have asked for surrender. The war is over. And everybody got out, went into the auditorium, somebody jumped at the piano, and started playing music. And my father led the conga line.

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: Dancing through there. Next morning people started tearing down the signs of the ghetto [indecipherable] district, and the Japanese arrested them. Oh, everybody said the whole thing was just a rumor, nothing true. But two or three days later, I think it was on the 14", a plane, American plane flew real low, dropping leaflets that the war is over, but the Japanese will have control, police control over the city until the Americans can come in. And then the emperor held his speech telling Japan and the whole world that the war is over.

These were two brothers, they were not married, two brothers who, in Liegnitz had department stores, something, but they came to San Francisco and lived there. And said, “Why do you go to Baltimore? Henry eventually had the job with this paper company, he stayed with them for over 40 years until he retired.

segments.question: Wow.
segments.answer: And we made friends. My parents made friends with other refugee people that lived there. I joined a fraternity, it had nothing to do with a college, it was like a club, and as I said, I’m still friends with these people today. A few years ago we had our 50 year reunion.

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: Just the three couples, one young -- one man moved onto New York and is now in upstate New York, and we call each other on the phone every once in awhile, once in awhile we see each other. So it was a very deep friendship that developed there. My brother also became friends with quite a few people, he had now a decent job, nine t -- nine to five, so to speak, rather than all hours of the day and night that they had in Bethlehem Steel. He had a car so he could get around. Began to teach me how to drive, which was --

segments.question: That was good.
segments.answer: -- it was good to a point. Eventually I went to a driving school, and --

segments.answer: Well, would -- he was so nervous because he had no controls, you know what I -- driving school the guy has all the controls there.

segments.question: Right, right.
segments.answer: And that -- so we had no intentions of leaving Baltimore to go to San Francisco.

segments.question: Did you want to go to school?
segments.answer: No. That’s my problem, I didn’t want to go to school. I liked -- I liked making money.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: I liked work, I liked making money. But people said to us -- used to say to us, in America you don’t need schooling. They don’t care about your schooling, it’s what you know that counts, what you can do that counts. Well, that’s not true. And eventually somebody said to my father, look, your boys don’t even have a high school diploma. You need to see to it that they get some schooling. So Henry and I went to night school, Baltimore City College, which although it has the name college in it, is really a high school. We went to night school, and sent our report cards from Shanghai to a department of education here in Washington. That eventually came back, and they just went by our age into which grade we should go. So in the meantime, what should we take, we -- English, of course, American history and some other subjects. We took tests in German for both German one and for German two, which we passed with about a 90 degree setting. And then we heard about the ga -- high school equivalent tests.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: And we both took that and passed that.

segments.question: So you got your high school degree.
segments.answer: So we have our high school degree. Recently I happened to come across a report card of that. I had 99 plus in mathematics, so mathematics was my field. But we didn’t go on to college. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. segments.question: And neither one of you wanted to?
segments.answer: Henry did go.

segments.question: He did?
segments.answer: He went to -- he went to Baltimore City College and took a two year course there. I was not eager at the time, which --

segments.question: Mm.
segments.answer: -- and I had no encouragement from my parents. In the meantime, my pa -- father had passed away, and my mother depended on Henry and I --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- to keep her going.

segments.answer: My father had a goiter from when he was a young man.

segments.question: Uh-huh.

segments.question: Right.

segments.answer: My father said, I don’t need that, this is just a beauty spot. People either like me or don’t like me with it --

segments.question: Right.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: -- one of the best hospitals in the world. He said, “But what about my heart?” I mean, now after the initial heart attack in Germany, he had had another heart attack in Shanghai.

segments.question: Mm-hm.

segments.answer: His heart just wasn’t able to take this, or whatever. Completely -- I -- I for one never expected him to die. That really got to me.

segments.question: Mm.
segments.answer: And my mother now depended completely on my brother and I to take care of her. No encouragement to me to go to school, so I didn’t. Two years later, 1951, I got drafted.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: And that -- after I come out of the army, instead of taking advantage of the G.I. bill, I went right back to work. My own fault, I should have gone to college. It would have been paid for under the G.I. bill. But with no encouragement, 1n just the other way, you know, you got to go back to work so you can support me, I went back to work.

segments.question: And who was supporting your mother when you were -- when you were in the army?
segments.answer: My brother.

segments.question: Your brother.
segments.answer: And I.

segments.question: And you, because you were sending back the money.
segments.answer: I sent back half of my pay, I mean, I got 80 dollars a month as a private, sent 40 bo -- dollars back home.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: While the other guys got money from home, I sent it back. And my brother was just above the age to be drafted, and the age was at 26, and --

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: -- so he just escaped being drafted.

segments.answer: Yes.

segments.answer: Yes. I knew her. And this -- also from -- she’s actually from Vienna. And they took an apartment just a few doors away from my mother’s house, or mother’s apartment, didn’t have a house, and my mother used to cook dinner for them. So they came over her house for dinner, and then went home. But then I came home, and I moved in with my mother and stayed there, and this is still in Baltimore. In the meantime I went back to Ritz camera centers, and they told me -- Eddie Ritz, a very fine man, you know, they had to send repairs out while you were gone, so now how about -- we think you’d be better salesman than a repairman. So I went into sales, worked my way up to assistant manager. And one day I got a call from Eddie Ritz out of Washington, we just bought this place called Brenner photo, how would you like to be manager of the store here in Washington? And that’s how I ended up in Washington.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: But instead of moving to Washington, my mother put it very bluntly, well, if you move to Washington, you’d have to pay for two apartments. So I commuted for about a year.

segments.question: Right. You don’t expect your children --

segments.question: Yeah. And you divorced in the 60’s, or -- This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection 4
segments.answer: No, late -- later on. When did I divorce? About 15 years ago -- no, 18 years ago, cause it was just before my oldest grandson was born.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: We divorced, there were many reasons for it, and once the children were out of the house, it became more obvious that we don’t fit together.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And it was a -- about as friendly a divorce as you can have, I guess. One day we just looked at each other and said, do we really want to continue our lives like that, and we decided no. So first I suggested she find a place to live, and then I would sell the house and I’d find a place to live, figuring it’s easier for a man to find an apartment than a woman. And she started to look around, she said, “Why would you want to sell this house, I mean, it’s something valuable that we have.” I said, “Well the house is too big for one person to live in.” Said, “Well if you don’t want it, then I want it.” I said, “Well, that’s fine, you know, I’ll find a place to live,” and I moved out. And you know, financial arrangements that we made between us hit some hard times, but not bad, not really bad.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: And she eventually remarried, and a few years later I met somebody and remarried.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And a good friend of mine asked me [indecipherable] how is marriage a second time around? I said, “Well, if it’s that much better the second time around, I can’t wait for the third time around.”

segments.question: So it’s a good relationship. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection 5
segments.answer: It’s a very nice relationship, we do a lot of things together, we travel a lot. We bo -- she’s also divorced, so we learned from our mistakes the first time.

segments.question: Yeah, right.
segments.answer: And any divorce, it’s not one person’s fault --

segments.question: It’s not.
segments.answer: -- it’s always two people who are not necessarily at fault, things just don’t work out right. There are many, many parts that --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- play a part in this.

segments.question: Whe -- when you look back, it’s -- in a way what I’m going to say is a stupid question, but -- because I don’t know exactly how you take something out of your life and say if -- what would have happened if this didn’t happen to me. segments.answer: I think I am aware of it.

segments.question: You are?
segments.answer: My life -- I mean, I look at what my life would have been like 1f Nazism wouldn’t have come to Germany.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: I would have gone to college, I would have become a doctor or lawyer --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- some professional.

segments.question: Right. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection 6
segments.answer: I would have had a great life, you know, I would not have had to worry about supporting my parents, they would have supported me. Probably would have gone into a profession where I could make -- I’ve made a decent living, and -- instead of what I ended up with. I mean, I didn’t do bad. Considering what I went through, I did very well.

segments.question: Right, right. And you enjoyed it, it seems.
segments.answer: I -- enjoyed most of it.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: And -- but I find -- I -- you know, I get together with people my age or even younger, and they talk about their college life, which I’d never experienced. I never experienced living by myself until I divorced.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: Because I went from my mother’s house, got married --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- into married life. The three years between my separation from my wife, and before I met Anya, I enjoyed those, because I was on my own.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: I was able to take care of myself, I didn’t starve.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: Figured out how to cook, more or less, and I missed out on that part of my youth. I never had a teenage life, or a young adult life. So yes, I missed that. I decided a couple of times to go back to take college courses, but didn’t really follow through on it. I did all right in my profession. I eventually, after I left Ritz Camera Center, went with a company called Industrial Photo, and This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. segments.question: Mm-hm.

segments.answer: -- have enough education of -- by reading and studying on my own. But certain things I just missed out on. You know, it -- like one time I tried to -- I considered opening up my own camera store, but then I became scared. I am not a big risk taker, I’d rather let other people take the risk and I work for them, but that doesn’t get you very far.

segments.question: But you were in a very high risk situation as a child, it makes perfect sense, doesn’t it?
segments.answer: Uh-huh, I guess.

segments.question: It wasn’t your choice, it was certainly --
segments.answer: It was not my choice.

segments.question: No, but it certainly was a high risk situation.
segments.answer: It was a very high risk situation, I mean, we escaped Germany --

segments.question: Barely.
segments.answer: -- barely escaped Germany. In Shanghai I got bombed out, I mean I easily could have been killed there.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And to think about what would have happened if we wouldn’t have left Germany --

segments.question: You wouldn’t be sitting here.
segments.answer: -- is really un -- I wouldn’t be sitting here.

segments.answer: Really be unthinkable.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: To realize what happened to my cousin, my uncles, my aunts, can’t -- I can’t dwell on that too long, it’s too horrible. You read some books and you wonder how one human being could do that to another.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And yet, it’s still happening today. Not necessarily against the Jews, but human beings can be very cruel.

segments.question: Right. Are you a religious person?
segments.answer: No, not at all.

segments.question: Do you think that this set of events destroyed the possibility of becoming religious, do you think, or were -- you were just -- weren't that way all along?
segments.answer: No, it has -- I think the last straw was my daughter’s death.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: Lalways say if -- there can’t be a God who can let six million people die, with one million of children, and then I say it’s really six million and one.

segments.question: And one, right.
segments.answer: So, I’m really an atheist in -- as far as my belief is concerned. I’m a cultural Jew, and ethnic Jew, but not religious.

segments.question: What is this shot here?
segments.answer: This is actually a shot of the Main Street of Liegnitz. Legnica 1s called now. At one point in Shanghai, somebody came across this as a picture postcard and gave it to my mother when they saw that it was town we were born in -- I was born in. And you see the streetcar on its single track down the street, and those two domes in the back, I don’t remember the name of the church, but was the center part of Liegnitz, and it -- the main shopping center. This must have been taken sometime in the early 30’s.

segments.question: And who is this couple?
segments.answer: These are my mother’s parents. Their last name was Lewy, pronounced Levy in German. His name is Isadore and her name is Rosa. And my grandfather had a little goatee, looks a little bit like Lenin. He -- what I remember about him is as a child he fell out of a tree, and they had to amputate one of his fingers. And when we went for walks, it always felt funny when that one finger was missing. He passed away in 1936, of a normal death, I forgot -- I have no idea what it was. But my grandmother lived on and then eventually ended up in Theresienstadt.

segments.question: And Ernie, who are -- who is this?
segments.answer: These are my father’s parents. I never met them. They died during World War I. I am not sure what they died of, it might have been from that flu epidemic that went all around the world at that time. But these pictures must have been taken before the 20" century started. I have the originals in the frame in my bedroom. And well I’m -- as I say, I don’t know too much about them.

segments.question: And their names?
segments.answer: Emil is his name, and now you got me, I don’t remember. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. segments.answer: I -- Hanne, I believe. I think it’s Hanne, well don’t quote me on this one.

segments.question: And this shot?
segments.answer: This is my father, his name was August, and -- on his motorcycle. He didn’t have the motorcycle any more by the time I was born. He and my mother cruised on the motorcycle all through Germany, and eventually they bought a car. And then when I came along, a bigger car. So the story goes that my brother asked once, why didn’t you buy a bus in the first place? But he loved gadgets like this, and people recognized when the doctor was visiting someplace by the motorcycle.

segments.question: Do you have any idea what year that was?
segments.answer: Well, it is probably in the 20’s, the mid- 20’s, because Henry was born in 1925.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: So it would have been before that.

segments.question: And this picture?
segments.answer: This is my whole family, my father, obviously doing quite well, not on a diet at that point. My mother, Betty, that’s me on her lap, and my brother Henry on the other side. This was taken when Henry and I had whooping cough, and we were out in the country someplace, and my father went to town to his practice, and then came ho -- back in the evening, and one day he came back with a brand new car.

segments.answer: This is my nursery school. The lady in the back is Miss Schroeder, who was the owner [indecipherable] of the school, and I’m the little guy right in front of her. segments.question: And this shot?
segments.answer: This was my first day of school. In Germany it was common practice that on your first day of school you got a cone filled with candy. That’s my brother, putting his hand on my shoulder for support. But I obviously enjoyed the candy afterwards.

segments.question: And this group?
segments.answer: This is my first year of school, my first grade class. I’m in the front in the center. They -- right there. And my teacher Mr. Thiel is in the background there.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: That’s him right there. Basically had a pretty good time in school there. And I reconnected with Mr. Thiel when I was in the military after World War -- after -- no, during the Korean War.

segments.answer: Well, this is me in my liederhosen. And it’s hard to tell who is more proud, my father of me, or me of my father. But I believe this was taken in the mountains not too far from where we used to live.

segments.question: And this?
segments.answer: This is probably on the second year in Shanghai. Both my brother Henry and I joined the British Boy Scout association. He as a scout, and I as a Wolf Cub. Here we call them Cub Scouts.

segments.question: A Wolf Cub?
segments.answer: It was referred to as Wolf Cub. This was actually taken across the street from where we used to live.

segments.question: And what do we see here?
segments.answer: Here we see what is left of the SACRA building after the bombing on July 17", 1945. You can see the bomb holes on top, and there’s a little gate in that wall that we used to enter in. The building has been razed, and there’s another apartment building in its place now.
